content: The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2014" amends the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act by revising the table of contents and enhancing the authority of the Council to require supervision and regulation of certain nonbank financial companies and bank holding companies. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is amended to enhance the authority of the Council to require supervision and regulation of certain nonbank financial companies and bank holding companies. The Council may determine that a bank holding company should be subject to enhanced supervision and prudential standards by the Board of Governors if it poses a threat to the financial stability of the United States due to financial distress or the nature of its activities. The Council uses the Basel Committee's indicator-based approach to determine systemic importance of bank holding companies based on size, interconnectedness, substitutes availability, global activity, and complexity. Certain bank holding companies are exempt from this determination. The text discusses exemptions for bank holding companies with total assets of $50,000,000,000 or less. It also mentions changes in subsections (d) and (e) through (j) related to the determination of systemic importance. The text discusses amendments to the Dodd-Frank Act related to enhanced supervision of bank holding companies. It includes changes in subsections (g) through (i) regarding the determination of systemic importance and enhanced supervision criteria. Amendments to the Dodd-Frank Act include changes in subsections related to enhanced supervision of bank holding companies. This involves adjustments in criteria for systemic importance and enhanced supervision. Amendments to the Dodd-Frank Act modify criteria for enhanced supervision of bank holding companies, specifically regarding total consolidated assets and final determinations under section 113. Amendments to the Dodd-Frank Act modify criteria for enhanced supervision of bank holding companies, specifically regarding total consolidated assets and final determinations under section 113. Additionally, revisions to board authority are made. Amendments to the Dodd-Frank Act remove the criteria based on total consolidated assets for enhanced supervision of bank holding companies. Instead, companies will be subject to final determinations under section 113. Management interlocks and prudential standards are also revised accordingly. Amendments to the Dodd-Frank Act eliminate the requirement based on total consolidated assets for enhanced supervision of bank holding companies. Companies will now be subject to final determinations under section 113. Management interlocks and prudential standards are also adjusted accordingly. Amendments to section 11 of the Federal Reserve Act now require bank holding companies to be subject to final determinations under section 113 of the Dodd-Frank Act, eliminating the asset-based threshold for enhanced supervision. Management interlocks and prudential standards are adjusted accordingly. The amendments made by this Act will take effect one year after enactment, except for Global Systemically Important Financial Institutions, which may undergo proceedings for determination under the Dodd-Frank Act but cannot receive a final determination before the effective date.
